posts.body:
>>214cd295-bf6f-4b36-ae19-abfa16218ab3
Why encode 300kB image? Picrelated is just 19893 bytes long (402x604 pixels), and still clearly recognizable. According to your formula it will cost only 0.0052 BTC or 43$ to instert a similar image in a bitcoin blockchain. It's affordable cost, I think. Just post link to a simple program which does not requre installation of any additional software and easy to use and somebody will definitely do it.

This is the image contained in the b3c4c8e41d235afd8b43ebc2b856e348162c3b043d39a6ce74c3d67e59e53359 bitcoin transaction. (Yeah, it's very small, 150x120 pixels).

Here is the thread explaining how to get and put files in a bitcoin blockchain:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/1H5YxVHvcfKM4STjJwyjYaBe8qbPyR6EZr:b:9ea42cb5-fb15-4de0-a8c3-b7f25fb1af0a

>>2aa99aa1-702a-4559-bd5f-4c0129ab76bc
Nicely done program, works like a charm! The image from earlier mentioned transaction posted in /cp/ board, for those who interested.

Waiting for a generous person who could spend 43 bucks on inserting something more explicit into blockchain...

>>82e95e32-8012-4afd-acf8-a5bf115ab7ad
It makes sense to run it on a testnet before actual use.
>>8e2d7142-a221-4475-9ace-3958270fb10e
This image was just an example, not a real thing (because I don't want post a real child porn in a /b/, it belongs to /cp/). Just grab something really hardcore from there or your hard drive.
I agree with the program author that the image must contain "something definite CP, that cannot be ignored or waved off". Anyway it's up to a person who will spend the money to decide what to insert.
Your results are good. Please write, how did you achieve that?

>>b2ad60bc-f6e0-4c3a-8c34-c54e0211c9fb
Image must be encoded as clear as possible without any hacks. It must be extractable by any program not just ours. All previous files presented in a blockchain somehow managed to avoid this sorting problem. Also adding metainforation will reduce a payload as you mentioned.
Maybe use a different client, not Electrum?

>>dcd8463c-3437-4ed9-962a-c6fa3aa8c4bc
I love your decision about private key.
It's time to create an image explaining how to extract rarjpeg and run this program, which will be embedded in the same image, and start to spread it on 4chan, 8chan, krautchan, reddit, 2ch.hk, etc.

>>a218e94a-88b4-4ae2-815c-04a5854f52d4
>just embed the files directly in the image that explains rarjpg.
Yeah, I meant exactly that. Sorry for my bad English.
>>fcea5c0e-0b16-4558-8f41-7bb7deba5981
How are already present files dealing with this problem? As stated in this paper https://fc18.ifca.ai/preproceedings/6.pdf, it's more than 1600 files already included in a bitcoin's blockchain.
About files detection I like the idea that they can be easily to find. Folks who want to hide something in blockchain, can use an encryption. Security through obscurity is a bad idea anyway.

>>e2b30a1e-e1ea-43a1-9105-6f6f0ce6e54d
>They will still be easy to find
Do you mean they can be found by looking for file signatures? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_file_signatures 

>the network could decide to reject these 'file-transactions'
You have a point, I never thought about that. We need to hurry.
I like this idea. Nobody still done that?
